awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Linking High 3He/4He to Other Isotopic Systems in Baffin Island Lavas
awd_abstract_narration:
Rare volcanic rocks with isotopically light helium (i.e., high 3He/4He ratios) are thought to contain material that ascended in plumes from early formed and long isolated reservoirs at the base of Earth's mantle. Lavas erupted on Baffin Island in arctic Canada have the highest 3He/4He ratios found in any terrestrial rocks and thus afford the best  opportunity to investigate the stratification and long-term evolution of the deep Earth. This project will employ novel geochemical techniques to study a suite of high 3He/4He lavas collected on Baffin Island in 2018. The primary objective of the project is to improve our understanding of helium behavior in magmatic settings. Combined with a thorough petrologic and geochemical assessment of the samples, our results will provide new insights about deep Earth processes. This collaborative project will support graduate students and highly specialized technical support staff at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and California Institute of Technology. The project team also will partner with a Massachusetts-based rehabilitation center to provide employment opportunities to local residents. All results will be published in peer-reviewed journals, as well as translated into Inuktitut and shared with the Baffin Island Inuit communities that assisted with fieldwork.

Understanding the composition and the long-term evolution of the deep Earth relies on an ability to link high 3He/4He ratios to other chemical components in volcanic rocks. This study will investigate helium (de)coupling from other elements by combing detailed petrographic and geochemical observations with precise 3He/4He measurements. The project will utilize innovative techniques including helium diffusion experiments, X-ray computed tomography, laser ablation micro-drilling, and single-grain crushing to investigate helium mobility in olivine crystals, which are the primary hosts of helium in the lavas. To fill knowledge gaps about Baffin Island lava geochemistry, researchers also will measure 186Os, 182W, and heavier noble gas (Ne, Ar, and Xe) isotopic abundances. This comprehensive geochemical assessment of these understudied lavas will offer a fresh perspective on enigmatic deep Earth processes. This collaborative project will support graduate students and highly specialized technical support staff at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and California Institute of Technology. Project members will partner with a Massachusetts-based rehabilitation center to provide employment opportunities to local residents. All results will be published in peer-reviewed journals, as well as translated into Inuktitut and shared with the Baffin Island Inuit communities that assisted with fieldwork.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Principal Investigators of this collaborative award and a graduate student had a unique opportunity to conduct fieldwork and collect samples from the volcanic rocks exposed on two remote islands and along the eastern coast of Baffin Island in Arctic Canada (Figure 1). NSF support was sought to complete a series of analyses in order to maximize the scientific return from this expedition and the resulting unique sample collection.

The volcanic rocks in this area of Baffin Island were already known to be of special interest to geochemists because of their relationship to the opening of the Labrador Sea, possible relationship to ongoing volcanism at Iceland, high temperatures of eruption, and especially the isotopic ratios of the noble gasses trapped in their crystals. The noble gasses -- Helium (He), Neon (Ne), Argon (Ar), Krypton (Kr), and Xenon (Xe) -- are especially valuable tracers of chemical reservoirs in the Earth because they don't easily react with other elements and because some of their isotopes are primordial (e.g. 3He and 20Ne) whereas others are made by radioactivity in the Earth (e.g. 4He and 21Ne). Samples with high 3He/4He and 21Ne/20Ne indicate derivation from sources that have preferentially retained their primary gas content over geologic time. The Baffin Island lavas were already known to have the highest 3He/4He of any volcanic province on Earth and hence may be the purest samples we have of this undegassed reservoir, presumed to reside in the lower mantle (deeper than 670 km) and be occasionally brought to the surface by high temperature plumes.

Our study has yielded a number of significant new results from these lavas:

1. We broke the record for highest 3He/4He, finding a sample with a reproducible and precise ratio 67.2 +/- 1.8 times higher than that of the atmosphere (the previous record was 50). (Figure 2) We have constructed an argument that these data are best explained by He leaking out of the core and into the lowermost mantle.

2. We measued the oxidation state of Fe in melt inclusions in olivine crystals in the rocks (Figure 3), obtaining the first constraints on the oxidation state of these magmas.

3. The Ne isotope ratios provide a definite link to the Iceland hotspot, showing consistency in the reservoir feeding this plume over 60 million years.

4. The magnetic stratigraphy shows very rapid eruption of the entire volcanic sequence, yet there was little impact of this volcanic event on the biosphere.

There is more information that can be gained from this well-curated sample collection. The sample locations and metadata are bring posted to discoverable sample archives so that investigators can find them, ask for splits, and make their own measurements.

Broader impacts: This work supported the educaton of two graduate students, a non-profit that employs persons with disabilities, the curation of a world-class sample collection for shared use by geochemists, and engagement with the indigenous Inuit people of Baffin Island.


Last Modified: 10/30/2022
Modified by: Paul D Asimow

Images (1 of )
  • Basalts of the Baffin Island sequence outcrop on Padloping Island (Paallavvik), in the foreground, and on Cape Searle (Qaqaluit) in the background.
    Joseph Biasi
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Paul D Asimow
    PI Paul Asimow on Baffin Island
  • He isotope ratios expressed in multiples of the atmospheric ratio. Normal mid-ocean basalts have a ratio near 8. Hotspots like Hawaii and Iceland commonly have ratios as high as 25. The previous record, also from Baffin Island, was 50. We have a reproducible sample at 67�1.8, the highest ever seen.
    Forrest Horton
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Paul D Asimow
    He isotope data from Baffin island samples
  • In electron microscope images, brightness is proportional to heavy element content, in this case mostly Fe. The light grey is glass; the dark grey patches are olivine crystals. The white are spinel crystals. The red circles show points analyzed for chemistry by electron microprobe
    Xenia Boyes
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Paul D Asimow
    Back-scattered electron image of glass and crystals in Baffin Island sample
